awd_titl_txt: CNH-S: The New 100th Meridian: Urban Water Resiliency in a Climatic and Demographic Hot Spot
awd_abstract_narration:
John Wesley Powell, famed American explorer and first U.S. Geological Survey director, popularized the 100th Meridian as the climatic boundary between the humid east and the semi-arid west - the geographic origin of the western United States. There is good agreement among climate models indicating a warmer and probable drier future for central Texas. As such, the transitional boundary between the humid east and semiarid west is shifting eastward from the 100th Meridian. The major cities of San Antonio, Austin, Dallas, Fort Worth, and the Rio Grande Valley are located just east of the 100th Meridian, and rank among the fastest growing regions in the U.S. The state is projected to double in population by the year 2065. The central Texas corridor's position near the climatic boundary makes it particularly sensitive to changes in temperature and precipitation. Couple climate change with rapid population and economic growth, and man-made forces become an important driver of future water scarcity in times of drought. It is because of these twin drivers of climate change and population/economic growth that the central Texas corridor can be viewed as a sentinel community; that is, the changes that are currently underway in the region may predict trends for other parts of the U.S. Thus, research will be conducted on climate, population, urbanization and water resources in this region, as it is a valuable proving ground for new techniques and strategies to address water scarcity.

The research comprises: 1) Identifying the Grand Challenges for understanding Texas water resiliency; 2) comparison of 21st century climate model projections at high spatial resolution and improving our understanding of the mechanisms that drive drought in Texas; 3) development of scenarios of demographic changes and regional development for the 21st century in Texas; and 4) integration of the above into a regional evaluation of future water resiliency for the state. New research activities will bring together researchers from complementary disciplines to initiate collaborations and synthesize research activities. The overarching goal of this research is to build knowledge regarding the factors that will impact future water resiliency in the rapidly changing human and natural systems of Texas, which will have applicability to other regions for which significant population growth and changing water availability are projected.

por.por_cntn:
This project was an interdisciplinary, multi-institution collaboration centered on enhancing water resiliency in Texas by identifying Grand Challenges for understanding water resilience, comparing climate model projections at high spatial resolution to illuminate drought mechanisms, and developing scenarios for population growth, demographic change, and regional development in the 21st century.

 

This project directly led to the creation of the Texas Water Research Network (TWRN - https://www.esi.utexas.edu/research/texas-water-research-network), the primary collaborative vehicle for facilitating 270+ researchers and stakeholders to engage in projects around four themes with specific priorities:

 

Water Science

1.     Discerning to what extent can/should we incorporate Big Data into hydrologic monitoring programs and how these programs might change depending on short time periods (e.g., floods) and long-time periods (e.g., water resource planning).

2.     Assessing the impacts of urbanization on urban water quality and quantity.

 

Stakeholders and Resiliency

1.     Improving our understanding of the water related data landscape in the region.

2.     Strengthening connections between Texas Water Research Network (TWRN) stakeholders and policy makers.

 

Climate Projections

1.     Consolidating and integrating disparate knowledge about climate change and hydrologic systems and resulting water-related vulnerabilities.

2.     Working to fill existing knowledge gaps on the impact of climate change on regional water supply issues while identifying potential unexpected risks.

 

Future Scenarios

1.     Developing a robust demographic approach toward quantifying future water provisioning in Austin and San Antonio, Texas as a function of projected population densities, socio-economic status, and other relevant parameters.

2.     Determining long-term impacts of rapid population expansion, new water technologies (e.g., managed aquifer recharge, direct wastewater reuse, etc.), and governance on Texas water availability, sustainability, and resilience.

 

Key Outcomes

 

Using multiple regional climate models, we project that Texas, and specifically West Texas, will be drier in the late 21st century than at any other time in the past millennium, even centuries that included mega-droughts (Figure 1; Nielsen-Gammon et al. 2020). Using this information, we examined future changes in water budget as they relate to opportunities for reservoir management. We then aligned the climate science to stakeholder needs by examining four case studies from the perspectives of 1) agricultural producers, 2) large surface water suppliers, 3) small groundwater management districts, and 4) regional water planning groups.

 

Research results from seven Austin-area watersheds demonstrate that some streams are composed of up to 90% municipal water. By measuring cation and anion concentrations and Sr isotope composition, we constructed mixing models and mass balance models to diagnose the aqueous signatures of two urban stream processes: 1) dissolution of host bedrock carbonate minerals, and 2) water-rock interaction, wherein host bedrock carbonate minerals dissolve and calcite reprecipitates, causing an enrichment of trace elements and Sr isotope composition (Figure 2; Beal et al. 2020).

 

A social network analysis of the TWRN found that members were relatively well connected, but that some research groups were way more active and connected than others. (Figure 3; Bixler et al. 2019). Results from this assessment helped us to steer the TWRN toward collaborating in topically focused workshops that in the past year have resulted in a synthesis publication of the cascading failures in Texas water infrastructure during Winter Storm Uri (Figure 4; Glazer et al., 2021) and one manuscript addressing challenges to ensuring equity and sustainability in policy and infrastructure for Texas water resources in the 21st century (Cook et al., in prep).

 

The last phase of this study explored the relationship between demographics and domestic water consumption using residential water consumption data and tax appraisal data for more than 300,000 single-family homes in San Antonio. Using hierarchical modeling, we found that the presence of a swimming pool, residential parcel acreage, size of living space, parcel appraised value, and per capita income are good predictors of variation in residential water consumption (Figure 5; Potter et al., in review). These data will allow a first-order calibration between socioeconomic indicators and water demand, enabling future scenarios modeling as a function of choices in city policy (e.g., high density vs. low-density housing) and demographic trends.

 

In addition to sparking the creation of the TWRN, ideas from this project have been used to create two NSF REU Sites (EAR #2051110, EAR #1560451 – 32 students), two undergraduate summer research institutes focused on engaging underrepresented minorities from non-research institutions funded by the Cynthia and George Mitchell Foundation (6 students), one NSF Sustainable Urban Systems conference of 45 participants from 28 unique interdisciplinary backgrounds (CBET #1929942), and one NSF Hydrologic Sciences study of the temporal evolution of infrastructure failure and its coupling to water quality degradation (EAR #2055536). This project created opportunities for 9 undergraduate and 13 graduate students to contribute to abstracts, journal articles, conferences, networking meetings, and research activity and training (see Research Products). Results from this project have been incorporated into several undergraduate and graduate courses that engage more than 350 students on an annual basis.
